U of L soccer team rallies over Saint Louis

Cardinals will host Maryland-Baltimore County in third round of NCAA tournament.

U of L soccer team rallies over Saint Louis

Kenzie Winstead, The Courier-Journal 9:32 p.m. EST November 23, 2014

Louisville Cardinals' midfielder Ben Strong, left, hugs teammate Louisville Cardinals' midfielder-defender Tim Kubel after Kubel scores the winning goal against the St. Louis Billikens, beating them 2-1 to advance in the NCAA soccer playoffs. 23 November 2014 (Photo: , David R. Lutman/Special to The CJ)

2 CONNECT 17 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

The seas are parting for the University of Louisville men's soccer team.

The 13th-seeded Cardinals scored twice in the last 20 minutes and rallied past 19th-seed Saint Louis 2-1 Sunday night before 1,714 at Dr. Mark & Cindy Lynn Stadium as driving rain storm pounded the turf.

U of L (11-7-3) now advances to the third round of NCAA Men's Soccer Championship.

The Cards will host again Sunday, when they face Maryland-Baltimore County (13-5-4) at 6 p.m.

"To be one of the last 16 teams and to host it is awesome," U of L coach Ken Lolla said. "I told the team the good news is we get to have Thanksgiving together and the better news is we get to host. It's all good."

UMBC shocked No. 4-seed Maryland 1-0, and No. 5-seed Indiana lost to Xavier 2-1.

The Billikens (14-5-2), who beat U of L 1-0 on Sept. 9, struck first. After a scoreless first half, Saint Louis got on the board with with the aid of a corner kick.

Louisville Cardinals' midfielders Ivan Gutierrez, left, Ben Strong, center, and midfielder-defender teammate Tim Kubel celebrate after Kubel scores the winning goal against the St. Louis Billikens, beating them 2-1 to advance in the NCAA soccer playoffs. 23 November 2014  (Photo: , David R. Lutman/Special to The CJ)

    After the corner kick, the Billikens' Filip Pavisic took a shot that was deflected by U of L goalkeeper Joachim Ball. On the rebound, Francisco Vizcaino flied toward the goal and applied a goal-scoring header in the 68th minute for the Billikens.

    The Saint Louis lead didn't last long.

    U of L scored when Tim Kubel took the ball on the right side and fed a pass to Andrew Brody deep in the mouth of the goal. Brody punched in his fifth goal of the season at the 70:15 mark.

    "We had great crosses the whole game," Brody said. "I had made a lot of runs before that. I just kept doing it and having trust in my teammates to put it on a spot where I could finish it. It was the easiest goal of my life, pretty much."

    Brody said the Cards kept positive, even after falling behind in the second half.

    "I thought we all stayed positive," Brody said. "We knew it was coming. ... We kept doing what we do. We didn't change anything at all."

    Kubel, a freshman from Germany, socred his seventh goal of the season when he weaved his way through traffic and fired in a shot from about 10 yards out.

    COURIER-JOURNAL

    Louisville soccer seeded 13th in NCAA tournament; Cardinals to host Sunday

    "I was kind of falling and I hit it with my left foot as hard as I could," Kubel said. "I knew the ground was slippery so I just hit it on the surface."

    Lolla said the crowd helped U of L.

    "We're so glad we had the first one at home because I believe it was a huge difference in the game," the U of L coach said.

    "It was tough, physical, hard-nosed game and I thought we kept our composure and we found a way to win the game," Lolla said.

    The U of L coach said a rugged schedule helped the Cards, who endured a four-match losing streak in the middle of the campaign.

    "I think the schedule we played this year really prepared us well," he said. "We knew how to win. That was huge."

    Saint Louis coach Mike McGinty said his team got worn down a little.

    "We kind of ran out of gas," McGinty said. "It was tough at the end of the game."

    As the season has gone along, Lolla said his team has learned to love each other.

    "I think we liked each and we're good buddies (earlier in the year)," Lolla said. "We didn't love each other enough. What you will see, this now loves each other and it shows on the commitment they offer on the field to each other. That has changed."

    Louisville 2 (Andrew Brody, Tim Kubel), Saint Louis 1 (Francisco Vizcaino).
